content.raw:
I've set this scenario up using DART \(in terms of joints rather than generic frames\), and DART's FK gives the exact same surprising result for D’s linear acceleration as `ign-physics` does here.

Granted, I also wrote DART’s FK, but DART has exhaustive unit testing on its FK computations, including tests for velocities and accelerations, so I’m inclined to trust it. Also, DART computes FK using spatial coordinates \(as opposed to the Newton-Euler method we’re using here\), so it seems especially unlikely that two very different formulations would each be flawed in just the right way that they produce the same incorrect result.

I think it’s still worth analytically deriving the acceleration just so we have concrete verification that this is the acceleration that we should expect, but it’s probably not worth looking for bugs in the code unless we find that an analytical solution disagrees with the results.
